Sección

• This activity is destined for Basic 2 students, if you have a lower level it might be difficult for you to comprehend and answer some activities. 
  • To answer this activity you need to have previous knowledge about present simple, you need to be familiar with the idea of auxiliary verbs in questions and negative sentences. 

Let's find out more information about traveling...

Q E R T P J v b ñ t o

Survey
Text and Tasks
What will you learn?
University of Auckland
Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

• In this material you will learn about the uses of simple past, and you will complete some activities about this topic to evaluate what you learned. 
  • You will also learn the structures of affirmative, negative and interrogative sentences in simple past to help you express events your own experiences in the past.
  • You will recognize and identify some regular and irregular verbs through traveling experiences.
Previous knowledge activity
Let's see if you remember simple present!
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Fill in the missing words to complete the sentences in simple present. Use the verbs in parentheses and the corresponding auxiliary verbs, also use capital letters when necessary. Do not use contractions.

When you finish completing the sentences click on "Submit" to evaluate your answers. If they are marked in green, they are correct; but if your answers are marked in red, there is something wrong. 

You can click on "Restart" to answer the activity again. 

To see the correct answers click on "Show answers".
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. How often do you exercise ? (exercise)

2. Does she eat breakfast before class? (eat) 

3. I do not like  to eat vegetables. (not like)

4. Do you visit the dentist regularly?   (visit)

5. He never takes showers in the morning. (take)

6. We do not run  in the mornings, we do it in the afternoons. (not run)

7. Do they wear a uniform at school? (wear)

8. She does not cook  at night. (not cook)
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Do not forget! 

Do is an auxiliary verb in English. 

We use do to make negatives and question forms.

Question (?) form

To make the question form of most main verbs in present simple, we use do, does (he, she, it) followed by the subject and the main verb:

Do you playfootball?

Does he play football?

Negative form

The negative of the present simple of all main verbs (except for be) is made with auxiliary do + not, which is shortened to don’t (do not), doesn’t (does not). We use the short forms in everyday informal language, and the full forms in more formal situations:

I don’t want to wait for a bus. Let’s get a taxi.

Jack doesn’t live in the town centre. He’s out in the suburbs.
Do you like to travel?

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

Before we start, answer the questions in your notebook. 


1. What comes to your mind when you think of the word "travel"?

2. Do you like traveling? Why?

3. In your opinion, which is the best place to travel?
Simple Past
What is simple past?
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

Which is your favorite childhood trip? Think about it, and how you would describe it to someone else. In order to do that, you need to use past tense. Specifically, you need simple past. Simple past tense is what you use when you are talking about something that has been completed in a definite time. 

How long the action or activity lasted doesn't matter for simple past, as long as it is no longer happening.

Uses of past simple tense: 

  • To talk about completed actions.

Example: I watched a James Bond film yesterday. 

  • To talk about repeated actions in the past.

Example: I went four times to the movies last month.

  • To talk about general truths about the past. 

Example: Fifty years ago, people did not have cell phones.

What are signal words for the Simple Past?

These words tell you which tense you have to use. For the Simple Past they are expressions of time in the past.

  • yesterday
  • last week
  • a month ago
  • in 2010
  • this morning

Here are some examples:

  • What did you do in your last holidays?
  • His parents married in 2004.
  • I didn't text my friend yesterday.
  • Did you miss the bus this morning?
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.
Affirmative sentences
How do we form the simple past?

Analyze the following information and answer the activities. 

AFFIRMATIVE

To form affirmative sentences in simple past, we need to take into consideration the regular and irregular verbs.

The past simple of regular or irregular verbs, in their affirmative form, have this structure:

subject + conjugated verb + rest of the sentence

Regular: we add -ed at the end of the verb:

Examples: I baked delicious biscuits yesterday.

                   I studied a lot for the exams.

Irregular: The irregular verbs change. 

Examples:  I got home at midnight. 

                   My best friend lost her wallet. 

English has two types of verbs in the past : regular  and irregular verbs. Here are the rules for these verbs. 

There are no specific rules for irregular verbs, you just have to memorize them. There are many irregular verbs, here is a list of some of the most common irregular verbs. If you do not know the meaning of any of these verbs, use a dictionary or click here.

6. My family  lived in the United States for five years. (to live)

7. We carried the suitcases from the airport to the hotel. (to carry)

8. The train stopped at the station for ten minutes. (to stop)

Remember: 

The simple past of the regular verbs in English are formed by adding '-ed' to the infinitive of the verb.

order - ordered / work - worked / live - lived / carry - carried / stop - stopped

There are no specific rules for irregular verbs.

Negative sentences
How to form negative sentences in simple past?

We need an auxiliary verb to form sentences in simple past: did

Structure: subject + negative auxiliary (did not) + base form of the verb + rest of the sentence

Do not conjugate the main verb after did not (didn't).

More examples: 

  • He did not visit his grandmother. 
  • We did not play soccer last week.
  • They did not see the movie yesterday.
Text and Tasks
Let's practice!
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Read the following sentences about the activities that Michel DID and rewrite them describing what Diana DIDN’T do.  Complete with simple past in negative form. USE CONTRACTIONS IN ALL THE SENTENCES. Look at the example:

Michel prepared his things for school on Sunday night.
You write: Diana didn’t prepare her things on Sunday night.

When you finish completing your answers click on "Submit" to evaluate them.

Click on "Show answers" to see if you respond correctly.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. Michel went to London last summer.  

Diana didn't go to London last summer.

2. Michel had a great time on vacations.

Diana didn't have a great time on vacations.

3. In the train station, he met the love of his life.

In the train station she didn't meet the love of her life.

4. Michel lost his passport.

Diana didn't lose her passport.   

5. Michel called his parents to ask for help.

Diana didn't call her parents to ask for help .

6. Michel's parents sent money to help.

Diana's parents didn't send money to help .

7. Michel missed his plane back home. 

Diana didn't miss her plane back home.

8. Michel bought a new plane ticket to go home. 

Diana didn't buy a new plane ticket to go home.

9. Michel arrived home very tired. 

Diana didn't arrive very tired.

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Do not conjugate the main verb when you use the auxiliary verb: did
Interrogative sentences
How to form questions with simple past?

To form Interrogative sentences in simple past you also need the help of the auxiliary verb did.

Structure: (Wh- word) Did + subject + infinitive verb + rest of the sentence + question mark

There are two types of questions: yes/ no questions and information questions, here you can see how they can be formed.

Remember that when you use the auxliary verb did  you do not need to modify the main verb.

If the question starts with DID, you can give a short answer using DID. It is not necessary to use the main verb in the answer.

Examples

Did you sleep well last night?
Yes, I did / No, I didn't.

Did the airplane arrive on time?
Yes, it did / No, it didn't.
Text and Tasks
Let's practice what you learned!
Provide instruction on how the True/False Question should be completed.

Analyze each question, choose true if it is written correctly, if not choose false. 

Example:  When did you arrive home?   - true
University of Auckland
Enter any feedback you wish to provide to the learner. This field may be left blank. if this field is left blank default feedback will be provided.
A hint may be provided to assist the learner in answering the question.

True/false questions present a statement where the learner must decide if the statement is true. This type of question works well for factual information and information that lends itself to either/or responses.
Type the question stem. The question should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.

It is correct!

Let's practice!
Ben's story
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

Usually when we go on vacations, we expect everything to go well, but sometimes this is not the case. Read Ben's story about his last holiday. There are 8 mistakes in the verbs, find them to correct them. Once you find them write the correct sentences in your notebook then click on "Show feedback" to compare your answers.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.

Ben's vacation

Martin had a terrible day yesterday. It was the day of his vacation to Spain but it was a nightmare. He leave the house at 10 o'clock in the morning and catched a taxi to the airport.

Martin went to the check-in with his luggage. When the man who worked for the airline asked for his passport, Martin became very upset. Where was his passport? Martin realize he didn't had his passport with him. What a disaster!

He jumped back into the taxi and told the driver to take him home. The driver drived duickly and Martin arrived back at his house in twenty minutes.

He runned into the house and goed into his bedroom. He found his passport on the bedside table and left the house again. But the taxi be not there! Where was the taxi!

Martin jumped up and down angrily. "I don't believe it. The taxi left!" he shouted. He ran down the street and looked for another taxi.

After a few minutes, Martin found another taxi and told the driver to take him to the airport as quickly as possible. The traffic on the roads was very bad and, unfortunately, Martin's taxi arrived at the airport late. His plane left for Spain at 11.30 and Martin missed it. He was very sad and went to speak to the airline. They promised to get him a seat on an evening flight and Martin went home on another taxi to wait.
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.

The correct sentences are: 

1. He left the house at 10 o'clock in the morning and caught a taxi to the airport.

2. Martin realized he didn't have his passport with him.

3. The driver drove quickly.

4. He ran into the house and went into his bedroom.

5. But the taxi wasn't there!

The correct sentences are: 

1. He left the house at 10 o'clock in the morning and caught a taxi to the airport.

2. Martin realized he didn't have his passport with him.

3. The driver drove quickly.

4. He ran into the house and went into his bedroom.

5. But the taxi wasn't there!
Bad experiences?
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Have you ever had a bad experience travelling? What went wrong?

It doesn't have to be negative, you can write about your best travel experiences.  

Write a short paragraph telling your experience. Remember that you need to use the simple past to narrate events in the past. 

Be careful with the use of regular and irregular verbs.
Activity validation
Validate your activity

Duration:
10:00

To finish this activity you will answer a validation quiz. It is important to consider these things:

       1. To get this activity validated, you must score at least 80% in this quiz.

       2. In order not to lose points, it is important to check not only your answer but your spelling too.
